bestBHT.bht: Amidst the crowd, women lamented and cried aloud, displaying their deep sorrow for Jesus. Luke's Gospel highlights the absence of hostility from women towards Christ, emphasizing their natural sympathy at such a time. These women of Jerusalem remind us that even in the darkest moments, God preserves a remnant and brings forth fruit. God, the righteous judge, does not passively observe, but sits to punish the unjust cruelty of men.

John Calvin: ...in the midst of that miserable dispersion, God reserved for himself a small remnant.

...when the wickedness of men breaks out into unrestrained disorder, God does not indolently look on, to see what they are doing, but sits as a judge in heaven, to punish them soon for their unjust cruelty.
Philip Schaff: A great number of the people. The ordinary crowd at an execution.
These were not the Galilean women (Luke 23:49), but women of Jerusalem (Luke 23:28).
This does not of itself indicate any real attachment to Him. It was the natural sympathy usual to the sex at such a time.
Archibald T. Robertson: In the Gospels there is no instance of a woman being hostile to Christ" (Plummer).
Luke's Gospel is appropriately called the Gospel of Womanhood.
Lamented (εθρηνουν). Imperfect active of θρηνεω, old verb from θρεομα, to cry aloud, lament.
John Gill: those that are executed by the sanhedrim, מתאבלין עליהן אין, 'they do not mourn for them'; but their near relations come and ask the peace of, or salute the witnesses, and they salute the judges, to show, that they have not any thing in their hearts against them, seeing they have passed a true sentence; but though they do not use mourning, lo, they grieve for them; for there is no grief but in the heart."

all that are put to death by the government, although they are executed by the order of the king, and the law gives power to slay them, lo, 'they mourn for them'; and they do not restrain any thing from them, and their substance goes to the king, and they are buried in the sepulchres of their fathers; but all that are put to death by the sanhedrim, 'they do not mourn for them'; but they grieve for them; for there is no grief but in the heart; and they are not buried with their fathers, till their flesh is consumed; and their substance goes to their heirs.

some expressed their concern and sorrow through a natural tenderness of spirit, and from a principle of humanity, being grieved that so useful and innocent a person, as Christ appeared to be, should be put to such a cruel and shameful death; and others from a spirit of gratitude, they, or their friends, having received cures from him, being healed by him of sicknesses, or dispossessed of devils; and others from a spiritual, as well as natural affection for him; among whom were his own mother and his mother's sister, and Mary Magdalene, and other women that followed him out of Galilee.

bhtAttempts.bht: Amidst the crowd, there were women who lamented and cried aloud, showing their deep sorrow for Jesus. These women, though not the Galilean disciples, expressed their concern and grief from a place of tenderness, gratitude, and spiritual affection for Him. Luke's Gospel emphasizes the significance of women, as there is no instance of a woman being hostile to Christ. These women of Jerusalem exemplify the natural sympathy usually displayed by women in such circumstances. It is a reminder that even in the midst of darkness and cruelty, God still preserves a remnant and brings forth fruit in due time. Though wickedness may prevail, God, the righteous judge, does not passively observe, but administers justice.

Amidst the crowd, women lamented and cried aloud, expressing sorrow for Jesus. Luke's Gospel highlights the absence of hostility from women towards Christ. These women of Jerusalem displayed natural sympathy, gratitude for healings received, and a spiritual affection for Him. In times of darkness, God preserves a remnant and brings forth fruit. As the wickedness of men breaks out, God, the righteous judge, does not look on passively, but administers timely punishment for their cruel actions.

Amidst the crowd, women lamented and cried aloud, expressing sorrow for Jesus. Luke's Gospel emphasizes the significance of women, as there is no instance of a woman being hostile to Christ. These women of Jerusalem exemplify the natural sympathy usual to the sex at such a time. It is a reminder that even in the midst of darkness and cruelty, God still preserves a remnant and produces fruit in due time. The wickedness of men does not go unnoticed, for God acts as a judge to punish their unjust cruelty.

In the midst of the crowd, women lamented and cried aloud, displaying their profound sorrow for Jesus. Luke's Gospel highlights the absence of hostility from women towards Christ, emphasizing their natural sympathy at such a time. These women of Jerusalem remind us that even in the darkest moments, God preserves a remnant and bears fruit at the appointed time. As the wickedness of men manifests in unrestrained disorder, God does not idly watch but sits as a judge in heaven, ready to punish their cruel actions.
